Response to Allegation No. 4 – Holiday Visitation
In response to Mother’s claim that Father willfully denied her Christmas 2025 visitation in violation of the Court’s directive, Father respectfully states the following:
The Court’s November 12, 2025 order [Doc. 429], cited by Mother, indeed states that “the scant evidence [does not] provide a sufficient basis to deprive either parent of visitation during one of the child's last 4-5 holidays as a minor.” However, Mother’s characterization of that ruling omits the broader context in which Judge Hall issued it. The Court clarified that “[t]he prior orders in this case did not address holiday visitation and do not appear to contemplate that this case would still be pending for a second holiday season.” The holiday visitation ruling was issued not because prior orders required it, but because the case had lingered and no formal suspension of visitation had been entered. The Court therefore applied general principles of parental fitness in granting the motion.
Importantly, until that point, the only visitation ever authorized by the Court following the July 31, 2024 hearing was weekly family dinners. At that hearing, when Mother’s counsel inquired about starting reunification therapy, Judge Perryman responded: “No, not now.” He approved only weekly meals involving both parents and the children and deferred all broader visitation pending therapeutic progress. The written order subsequently entered — drafted by Mother’s counsel — deviated from that oral directive, but it still did not authorize overnight or holiday visitation with A.K. Nor did it suspend such visitation, which formed the procedural basis for the Court’s November 2025 ruling, not a substantive endorsement of readiness or therapeutic progress.
Father did not deny visitation in willful disregard of the Court’s order. Rather, as detailed in prior filings and incorporated herein, he informed Mother of a long-planned church retreat for A.K. during the holiday window, which was communicated on December 15, 2025, with the deposit having been paid months earlier. At the December 25, 2025 exchange, A.K. refused to leave with her mother despite Father’s efforts to facilitate the visitation. Father encouraged A.K. to go, suggested she give her mother a hug, and told Brittany directly that if she wanted to take A.K., she could. Brittany did not do so. Father complied with the holiday order to the extent possible under the circumstances, and his actions do not constitute contempt.
Response to Allegation No. 5 – History of Blocking Visitation and Holiday Interference
Mother asserts that Father has a “history in blocking any and all visitation” with A.K. and suggests this is why she was unable to exercise Christmas 2025 visitation. This assertion is both unsupported by the record and mischaracterizes the procedural history of this case.
From July 2024 forward, all visitation between Mother and A.K. was governed not by the Final Divorce Decree but by the reunification plan ordered by the Court following Judge Perryman’s in camera interview with A.K. At that hearing, Judge Perryman determined that traditional visitation should not resume immediately, stating clearly that only weekly joint meals with both parents and the children were to occur. When Mother’s counsel asked about reunification therapy, Judge Perryman replied: “No, not now.”
The written order entered in November 2024, drafted by Mother’s own counsel, reinforced the structure of weekly dinners and stated that expanded visitation would occur only after therapeutic progress and a report from the appointed counselor. Judge Hall later acknowledged that these earlier orders “did not address holiday visitation” and “do not appear to contemplate that this case would still be pending for a second holiday season.” The Court granted holiday visitation to Mother in November 2025 on procedural grounds—due to the absence of a formal suspension—not based on a finding that Father had ever blocked visitation or that A.K. was therapeutically ready.
Father complied with the reunification orders. He facilitated every weekly dinner, brought A.K. to counseling, and followed the framework as outlined by the Court. When Mother relocated to Clanton, Father continued to bring the children to her town, including before Christmas 2025 for a church service and dinner with Brittany’s father, further demonstrating cooperation.
The allegation that Father has a “history of blocking any and all visitation” is contrary to the record. In fact, the Court has previously declined to find Father in contempt. At the July 2024 hearing, Judge Perryman stated explicitly that Father’s conduct did not amount to contempt, recognizing the child’s unwillingness and the complexity of the situation. As A.K. expressed in July 2025 in her own words: “No!! Please I’m scared… I’m gonna have a nervous breakdown if I have to go.”
It is inaccurate to claim that Father “blocked” holiday visitation when, as detailed in the prior response, A.K. herself declined to leave with her mother on December 25, 2025. Father informed Mother in advance of A.K.’s church retreat, attempted to facilitate the exchange, and encouraged A.K. to go. At no point did he interfere with the order.
This pattern does not reflect obstruction. It reflects ongoing adherence to the Court’s directives under difficult circumstances involving a minor child with unresolved emotional resistance to visitation—resistance that the Court has acknowledged and structured its orders around.
Response to Allegation No. 6 – Father's Conduct and Court's Prior Warnings
Mother implies that Father has repeatedly acted in defiance of court orders and should have anticipated consequences based on prior court warnings. However, the record does not support a finding that Father has acted in willful disregard of the Court’s authority or prior orders.
At the July 31, 2024 hearing, Judge Perryman expressly stated that Father’s conduct did not constitute contempt at that time. The Court acknowledged the unusual and sensitive circumstances surrounding A.K.’s emotional resistance to visitation. Following the in camera interview with A.K., Judge Perryman set aside the pending contempt hearing and outlined a clear plan: only weekly family meals were to proceed, and all further visitation or reunification steps would occur based on therapeutic progress. This plan was reiterated in the written order entered in November 2024, drafted by Mother’s counsel, which did not provide for overnight or unsupervised visits with A.K., let alone extended holiday time.
Between July 2024 and November 2025, Father complied with the weekly dinner schedule, took A.K. to counseling, and never impeded Mother’s ability to participate in the reunification process. The reunification counselor, Kelly Turner, conducted only two sessions before withdrawing from the case. No further structured therapy occurred after her withdrawal, and the Court never issued modified orders expanding Mother’s access to A.K. beyond the existing weekly meal requirement.
When the Court granted holiday visitation for Christmas 2025—based on the absence of an order formally suspending visitation—Father attempted to comply. He informed Mother in advance that A.K. had committed to a church retreat from December 27–30 and had paid the deposit for that trip months earlier. On December 25, 2025, Father encouraged A.K. to go with her mother, urged her to give Brittany a hug, and left the decision in the child’s hands. A.K. refused, telling her mother directly that she was not ready and needed acknowledgment of past conduct in order to rebuild trust. At no time did Father interfere with the holiday exchange.
The Court has never found Father in contempt regarding visitation. Assertions that he has ignored court warnings or acted willfully to prevent Mother’s parenting time are not supported by rulings or the procedural history. The record instead shows a consistent and cautious judicial approach focused on gradual reunification and therapeutic readiness—not forced visitation against a resistant child’s will.
Further undermining Mother’s argument, she failed to exercise her regular custodial weekend immediately following the holiday. On January 1, 2026, she returned Bennett to Father at approximately 6:00 p.m. but did not return to pick him up for her scheduled visitation from January 2 through January 4. This occurred despite her claim that she coordinated exchange plans through counsel to avoid any confusion. No contact or attempt was made by Mother to retrieve Bennett for that visitation period. This omission reflects a lack of follow-through on Mother’s part and contradicts the narrative that miscommunications or Father’s actions have obstructed her access to the children.
Response to Allegation No. 7 – Alleged Withholding of Information and Mischaracterization of Trip
Mother claims that Father interfered with visitation and failed to provide information related to A.K.’s holiday plans, referring specifically to an “extracurricular trip.” This allegation is inaccurate and omits essential facts.
The trip at issue was not a generic extracurricular activity—it was a church youth retreat organized by First Baptist Church in Alexander City, Alabama, scheduled for December 27 through December 30, 2025, in Gatlinburg, Tennessee. Father informed Mother of the trip well in advance and sought her input and permission. On December 15, 2025, Father texted Mother stating:
“AK wants to do this… it’s $200. It’s 12/27 – 12/30. Do you have a problem with her going out of state to TN for it?”
He also attached the official link to the church’s Winterblast 2025 page, providing full details of the event and payment information. At no point did Mother respond with any objection or concern. Then, on December 26, 2025, Father sent another message to remind Brittany of the trip and offer her a chance to speak with A.K. before departure:
“AK leaves for TN in the morning for winterblast. I have to have her at the church at 7am – they return Tuesday. Call her tonight before she leaves.”
These texts, backed by screenshots, show clear communication, transparency, and an opportunity for Mother to participate. The claim that the trip was concealed is contradicted by this documented effort to inform and involve her.
In addition, Father made multiple efforts during the holiday period to support A.K. and Bennett’s contact with Mother. Before Christmas, he drove both children to Clanton, Alabama, so they could attend Brittany’s church’s candlelight service. Bennett participated in the service, and Father encouraged A.K. to stay as well. Afterward, Father drove the children to Prattville, Alabama, where Brittany, her husband Bradley, and the children joined Brittany’s extended family for Christmas dinner. The children even purchased and exchanged gifts with Brittany and Bradley’s daughter—gifts Father helped them shop for at Walmart.
On December 25, 2025, at 12:00 p.m., both children were present and prepared for the holiday exchange. Brittany asked A.K. to attend a family gathering at her husband’s family’s home. Father placed Bennett in Brittany’s car and encouraged A.K. to go. He told A.K. and Brittany, “This is between you and your mother,” and then went inside the house, deliberately removing himself from the situation. Approximately ten minutes later, A.K. came inside on her own. Father did not instruct her to stay or prevent her from going—he gave A.K. space to make her own decision and respected the Court’s order.
In light of the documented communication, prior in-person efforts to promote visitation, and lack of any objection from Mother prior to the trip, there is no factual basis for the claim that Father withheld information or impeded holiday visitation. The trip was not concealed, it was not unauthorized, and Father took every reasonable step to facilitate both the holiday exchange and A.K.’s church commitment.
Response to Allegation No. 8 – Clarification of Communication Regarding Pickup
Mother asserts that Father’s use of only one child’s name during a phone call was intended to exclude or imply that A.K. would not be made available for visitation. This assumption is incorrect and unsupported.
If Father referenced only one child (such as Bennett) during a call, it was not intended to imply that A.K. would be withheld. The name mentioned likely reflected the specific logistical detail being discussed at that moment—not an exclusion of the other child. At no time did Father state or suggest that A.K. would not be made available. In fact, A.K. was present and available for the December 25, 2025 exchange, and Brittany personally interacted with both children during that time.
The last contact between the parties prior to the holiday exchange occurred before Father left the December 21, 2025 family dinner in Prattville, Alabama. That gathering—attended by Brittany, her husband, their children, and Brittany’s extended family—did not conclude until approximately 10:30 p.m. Father then made the 1.5-hour drive back to Alexander City and did not have further communication with Brittany before the scheduled exchange. The fact that Brittany saw both children on December 25, spoke with A.K., and invited her to join a family event confirms that A.K. was not being hidden or withheld.
Father complied with the Court’s holiday order, and any mention of only one child during a phone call cannot be reasonably interpreted as an attempt to interfere with or mislead regarding visitation.
Response to Allegation No. 10 – Denial of Manipulation and Efforts to Support Mother–Child Relationship
Mother alleges that Father made disparaging remarks to the parties’ minor son, B.M., on Christmas Day, specifically claiming that Father told B.M. that “his Mother refused to allow him to play with his toys,” causing B.M. to be upset with her upon her arrival. This allegation is entirely false and misrepresents the events of that day.
On December 25, 2025, Father called Mother at 11:00 a.m., one hour before the scheduled 12:00 p.m. pickup time, to ask when she would arrive. Brittany confirmed that she was already on her way. Father did not inform Bennett that his mother was coming to pick him up until she had already arrived, specifically to avoid upsetting him in advance. When Father told Bennett that his mother was outside, Bennett became visibly upset about the transition.
To help ease the exchange and make the moment more positive, Father asked Brittany’s husband, Bradley, to take a picture of him with the children on the front steps. He also invited Brittany to take a picture with them, and she agreed. Because Bennett was still emotional, Father suggested that everyone do “pouting faces” in the photos to help lighten the mood and make it feel more playful. A copy of that photo is attached as evidence.
In further effort to support the transition, Father asked Bennett if he wanted to show his mom what Santa had brought. When Bennett said yes, Father invited Brittany and her husband into the home, and Bennett proudly showed them his new gaming PC in the playroom. During this brief visit, Father also introduced Bradley to his father. Afterward, everyone went back outside, and Father placed Bennett in Brittany’s vehicle.
The suggestion that Father told Bennett something negative about his mother is unsupported and contradicted by these actions. Father clearly made every effort to create a warm, peaceful, and emotionally supportive exchange—not one based in tension or manipulation.
Father has consistently gone above and beyond to support the children's relationship with their mother, including:
Moving Christmas (Santa) to December 23 to prevent B.M. from experiencing the emotional conflict of receiving gifts and then having to leave a few hours later on Christmas Day;
Facilitating calls between the children and Brittany the night before and the morning of Santa’s visit at his home;
Bringing both children to attend Brittany’s church’s candlelight service and to have Christmas dinner with Brittany’s extended family in Prattville on December 21;
Participating in a family dinner and Walmart outing just days before this filing, during which Brittany took pictures of Father with her infant daughter.
These events show a consistent pattern of cooperation and care—not alienation or manipulation. Father categorically denies making any statement to B.M. that would cast Mother in a negative light, and he strongly objects to the repeated use of language suggesting that he employs “manipulation tactics.” The documented facts show otherwise: that Father supports co-parenting and has acted in the best interests of both children.
Response to Allegations No. 11–14 – Clarifying the Christmas Exchange, History of Encouragement, Court Rulings, and Judicial Statements

Allegation No. 11 – Addie Kate Withheld During Exchange
Mother alleges that Addie Kate was “packing for her church youth trip” during the scheduled Christmas Day pickup, implying she was unavailable. This is false. At the time of the exchange on December 25, 2025, at 12:00 p.m., A.K. was not packing. Both children came outside for the exchange. Photos were taken of the family on the front steps. Afterward, everyone returned inside briefly so Bennett could show Brittany and Bradley his Christmas gifts. Father then placed Bennett in Brittany’s vehicle.
While outside, Brittany asked A.K. if she would like to go with her to a family gathering at Bradley’s family’s home. She told A.K. she would bring her back later that evening. Father encouraged A.K. to go, but did not pressure her. As the discussion continued between A.K. and her mother, Father stated:
“This is between you and your mother,”
and then went inside the home. About ten minutes later, A.K. came inside. Father did not interfere in their discussion and did not obstruct the visitation.
Mother’s additional claim that “Katie” was present in the home during this exchange is also false. Katie is not Father’s sister, but his sister-in-law, and she was not present at the home during the pickup. Dated and timestamped video surveillance footage from Katie’s residence confirms that she remained at her own home until approximately 3:00 p.m. on Christmas Day—three hours after the exchange occurred. The only other person present at Father’s home during the pickup was his father.
This is another unsupported accusation and a clear attempt to misrepresent the facts before the Court.

Allegation No. 12 – Leaving the Decision to A.K. and Alleged Alienation
Father did not unilaterally “leave the decision up to the child.” If Mother had wished to enforce the visitation or believed Father was obstructing it, she could have involved law enforcement, as she has on prior occasions. She did not do so. The Court has never found Father in contempt for these exchanges, and in fact, both counsel and the Court agreed after the in camera interview with A.K. that the previously scheduled show cause hearing would not proceed. That decision followed the Court’s acknowledgment that A.K.’s statements carried weight in determining visitation progress.
Accusations that Father has made “zero attempts” to support visitation or that he engages in “parental alienation” are direct attacks on his character and are not supported by the record. Father has encouraged visitation, attended therapy, facilitated communication, and followed the court’s orders. The in camera interview and court’s subsequent actions contradict Mother’s narrative.

Allegation No. 13 – History of Prior Orders and Motion to Clarify
Mother previously attempted to enforce visitation under an outdated version of the custody order, despite the fact that a newer Temporary Order was in effect. Her filing to enforce a superseded schedule prompted Father to file a Motion to Clarify, which was granted by the Court on August 7, 2025. That order confirmed the most recent order controlled and clarified that the schedule Mother was attempting to enforce was no longer valid. Both the April 14, 2025 Temporary Order and the August 7, 2025 Clarification Order are attached.
These events show that any confusion in the record stemmed from Mother’s attempt to act under a repealed order—not from Father’s conduct.

Allegation No. 14 – Court's Early Remarks About Custody and A.K.'s Role
Mother cites early remarks made by Judge Perryman, such as:
“I don't mind talking to her again and letting her know if she don't do what I tell her she's got to do, then I may have to change custody, and a ten-year-old can't tell us what we're going to do.”
These comments were made before the judge heard any evidence and before conducting the in camera interview with A.K. After speaking with A.K. directly, Judge Perryman shifted tone significantly. He ordered only weekly family dinners as visitation and denied reunification therapy, responding to Mother’s counsel’s question with:
“No, not now.”
He made clear that the Court would not force visitation without therapeutic support and emotional readiness. The in camera interview was central to this shift in the Court’s approach, demonstrating the judge’s responsiveness to the facts and to A.K.’s lived experience.

Response to Allegation 15: Parental Alienation & Reunification Therapy Issues
Father’s Compliance with Court Orders and Promotion of Mother–Child Contact
No Disregard of Orders or Parental Alienation: Christopher Blaine McGregor (“Father”) has scrupulously followed the court’s custody and visitation orders and, in many instances, exceeded their requirements to facilitate the children’s relationship with Brittany Gilliland (“Mother”). As Father affirms, “I have fully complied with all court-ordered visitation arrangements and often exceeded them to support the children’s relationship with their Mother.” Far from instilling distaste for Mother or alienating the children, Father has consistently encouraged contact and goodwill. For example, during holidays in 2024 – when the Final Decree did not entitle Mother to Thanksgiving custody – Father voluntarily arranged extra time for Mother to be with the children. He allowed Mother to have dinner with A.K. on Thanksgiving Eve and spend special time with the younger child, even though this was beyond what the court order required. On Mother’s Day 2025, Father helped both children prepare gifts for Mother and invited Mother to join A.K. for dinner – an offer Mother declined. Father still brought A.K. out to Mother’s car that day to ensure A.K. could hand over the gifts and personally wish Mother a happy Mother’s Day. These actions demonstrate Father’s good-faith efforts to nurture, not undermine, the mother–child bond.
Encouraging Communication: At no point has Father engaged in a campaign of disparagement or blocked the children’s communication with Mother. In fact, the record shows Father facilitated phone calls, gift exchanges, and counseling sessions aimed at reunifying Mother and A.K.. He has never spoken negatively about Mother to the children. The court’s Final Order explicitly forbids either parent from making derogatory remarks or alienating the children (¶¶13, 14, 22 of the Decree). Father has obeyed both the letter and spirit of those provisions. The only impediments to Mother’s relationship with A.K. have been those arising from A.K.’s own well-founded emotional reservations and Mother’s repeated failure to take advantage of visitation opportunities – not any interference or poisoning of the well by Father.
Father Did Not “Let the Child Control” Visitation: Allegation 15 claims Father allows the minor child to dictate visitation. This is incorrect. Father has encouraged A.K. to attend scheduled visits and therapy, but he also must respond to the reality of A.K.’s trauma and fear. Notably, on July 24, 2025 the Court (Judge Kevin Hall) explicitly ordered both parties “to parent and not permit the/a child to control the operations of this Court’s orders”. Father has abided by this directive. He continues to present A.K. for visits and urges her to spend time with Mother – he has not told A.K. she can refuse visitation. For instance, when Mother wanted A.K. to attend a family event in Clanton, Father was willing: he told Mother that although he personally was unavailable at that moment, “if Addie Kate felt comfortable going with Mother, then Mother was welcome to pick her up and take her”. In other words, Father opened the door for Mother to speak with A.K. and make her feel safe, making it clear “I would not stand in the way if our daughter was willing”. Mother never even attempted to talk to A.K. or follow up on that offer. This example shows that Father is not granting the child veto power over visitation – to the contrary, he invited Mother to reassure A.K. and proceed with the visit.
What Father refuses to do is forcibly drag a terrified child into a car against her will without addressing the underlying issues. As he explained, “I cannot in good conscience force our child into a situation that she finds scary or traumatic.” This approach is entirely consistent with the Court’s guidance. At the July 31, 2024 hearing (before A.K.’s in-camera interview), Judge Perryman emphasized that the goal was to avoid “screwing up” the child and to rebuild trust gradually: “we’re going to send everybody to counseling, and then we’ll be back here and see if we can’t get things better.” The Judge made clear that reunification therapy should start slowly – first with A.K. and her individual counselor, then joint sessions with Mother “after y’all have some indication … that things are progressing”. In line with that intent, Father has prioritized A.K.’s emotional well-being while encouraging her to heal and eventually resume normal visitation. He is not “controlled” by the child; he is following professional and court guidance to ensure that contact is meaningful and not harmful. Father remains ready to facilitate full reunification as soon as A.K.’s counselor or a reunification specialist advises that A.K. is stable enough to handle it.
Mother’s Pattern of Missed Visitations and Non-Participation
Mother Missed ~50% of Court-Ordered Reunification Dinners: The contempt allegation faults Father for allegedly withholding visitation, but the factual record shows it has been Mother who failed to show up to visitation opportunities. After the divorce, the Court ordered weekly “reunification dinners” to help reintroduce Mother into A.K.’s life (originally Wednesday evenings, later moved to Sundays). From January through August 2025, roughly 30 weekly reunification dinners were scheduled – and Mother missed more than half of them. Some she canceled in advance with flimsy excuses; others she simply no-showed, leaving A.K. waiting. Each absence is documented in text messages and logs (Exhibits A–C) – for example, on January 10, 2025, Mother asked to reschedule a dinner to Saturday morning, which Father agreed to, but then Mother never appeared at the rescheduled time. On February 12, 2025, Mother neither showed up nor gave notice, then later tried to blame Father by claiming she wasn’t informed of the plan (despite a standing court order and shared Google calendar). The pattern continued through the spring and summer: Easter Sunday (April 20, 2025) – Mother failed to participate; Mother’s Day (May 11, 2025) – Mother again skipped the chance to see A.K., aside from picking up the younger child; multiple Sundays in June–August 2025 – Mother would cancel last-minute or simply never respond to Father’s messages about meeting times. By August, Mother was outright refusing to come to the designated location (Alexander City) at all, insisting Father drive A.K. to meet her halfway – contrary to the court’s order that Mother exercise visitation in Alex City. In sum, Mother’s own choices “resulted in any disruption of visitation,” not Father’s actions. Father, for his part, kept every weekly dinner slot open, had the children ready and waiting, and frequently reached out to confirm Mother’s plans – only to be met with silence or cancellations. He even adjusted schedules repeatedly at Mother’s request (e.g. moving visits from Wednesdays to Sundays to accommodate Mother’s work and relocation). The undisputed record is that Father was present for every scheduled exchange; it was Mother who more often failed to appear or cut visits short.
Mother Missed ~75% of A.K.’s Medical Appointments: The allegation that Father blocks Mother from the child’s life is further disproven by Mother’s own absence at critical events like doctor’s appointments. Father has kept Mother informed of all major medical visits for the children. Yet Mother has attended only a small fraction of A.K.’s medical and therapy appointments since the divorce. The attendance log of health visits (Exhibit __) shows that Mother was a no-show for roughly three out of every four appointments. By way of illustration, at A.K.’s pediatric sick visit on August 28, 2023, the clinic records note “Brittany – No Show”, with Father having to accompany A.K. alone. This was not an isolated incident – it is representative of a trend. Mother consistently failed to appear despite having joint notice and rights, thereby forgoing opportunities to engage in A.K.’s health and daily life. It is ironic for Mother to accuse Father of blocking communication with the school or medical providers, when the reality is Mother seldom shows up even when she is expected. Father cannot be blamed for Mother’s own lack of involvement. To the contrary, Father has never barred Mother from any school or medical information – he has provided updates and even added Mother to shared calendars for events. If Mother missed a vaccine appointment or a school function, it was due to her absence or inattention, not because Father hid it from her. In fact, the Final Decree’s joint legal custody terms require both parents to confer on major decisions, and Father has abided by that – for instance, consulting Mother about A.K.’s counseling and inviting her input on activities. It is Mother who chose not to attend or sometimes not even to respond.
Mother Missed ~94% of A.K.’s Extracurricular Activities: Father also documents that Mother has rarely supported A.K. at her extracurricular activities. A.K. is an active pre-teen with sports and school events. Father ensured Mother was informed of all games, recitals, and activities, and the schedule was readily available. Yet Mother’s attendance has been abysmal. Out of A.K.’s entire 2024–2025 sports season, Mother attended only 1 of 12 of A.K.’s soccer games, 2 of 16 of her cheer/football games, and 0 of 30 basketball games. In total, Mother was present for just 3 out of 58 games – a 5% attendance rate, meaning she missed approximately 94% of A.K.’s events. Again, this underscores that if anyone has been absent from the child’s life, it is Mother. Father, by contrast, was at every game or practice, and even took on all the driving and expenses for these activities (often with no contribution from Mother). Father also made sure Mother knew she was welcome at all events; he never discouraged her from coming. Her near-total non-attendance speaks for itself. It is simply not credible for Mother to claim Father “alienated” the child, when Mother has voluntarily alienated herself by failing to show basic support and presence. As Father notes, he has “gone out of my way to facilitate Mother’s visitation, and it is Mother who has often been unable or unwilling to utilize the time allotted to her.” Any suggestion that Father prevented Mother from being involved is flatly false.
In summary, the evidence of the past two years shows Father has bent over backwards to include Mother – flexible scheduling, extra holiday time, constant communication – while Mother has spurned half or more of the opportunities given to her. This directly refutes Allegation 15’s premise that Father is the one flouting court orders or poisoning the children’s minds. On the contrary, Father’s compliance and facilitation are well-documented, and it is Mother’s pattern of non-compliance that has hindered her relationship with A.K.
Father’s Efforts to Encourage and Continue Reunification Therapy
Allegation 15 also accuses Father of “blocking reunification therapy.” The record proves the opposite. Father has been the driving force behind initiating, maintaining, and when necessary, re-starting reunification therapy between Mother and A.K. Far from impeding therapy, Father has diligently followed every court directive and even sought corrections when the process derailed due to no fault of his own.
Court’s Intent vs. Written Order: It is important to recall the court’s intended plan for reunification therapy. During the July 31, 2024 hearing (where the Court interviewed A.K. in camera), Judge Perryman made the gradual approach clear on the record: A.K. would first continue individual counseling (with Mother participating in some of those sessions), and only after progress was observed would a separate reunification therapist commence joint Mother–daughter therapy. The Judge specifically said Mother should attend counseling sessions with A.K.’s regular counselor “at least eight/ten times” and “that needs to start immediately”, and “then a separate reunification [counselor] after we get down the road with this a little bit and see if we can’t get things better.”*. Father understood this phased plan and agreed with it – it aligned with ensuring A.K. was emotionally ready. However, when the written order came out on November 6, 2024, it omitted the phase-in sequence and instead directed that reunification therapy with a specific counselor (Kelly Turner) begin right away. Despite concerns that this contradicted the court’s stated intent, Father complied fully with the November 6 order. He did not challenge or ignore it; rather, he promptly facilitated the ordered therapy: he allowed Mother’s attorney to choose the reunification therapist (Ms. Turner), let Mother set the initial appointments, and made A.K. available for every scheduled session.
Full Compliance and Participation: Father never impeded the reunification counseling. To the contrary, he went to great lengths to make it successful. He provided a shared Google calendar to both Mother and Ms. Turner to coordinate sessions and communicated his openness and availability for any appointment. Father made sure to attend with A.K. every session that was scheduled and communicated to him. He even rearranged other family plans – for example, cutting short a family Christmas gathering on December 23, 2024 – because Mother and Ms. Turner set a therapy session that day.
